chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    
        <s>
           I now ask the writer if he imagines that something can be eaten physically, slowly, and with sensation while receiving the sacrament with a physical mouth, except for what is suited to and subject to the senses?
        </s>
        <s>
            Does he want us to believe that the true body of Christ is consumed like ordinary food, being torn to pieces with teeth and swallowed bit by bit? No one can strictly hold or accurately defend this opinion.
        </s>
        <s>
            So, what troubles him in these words of Ratramnus? Is it not the sacramental appearances alone that are eaten physically, chewed by the teeth, and slowly and with sensation lowered into the chest through the throat, like manna?
        </s>
        <s>
            Do Paschasius, Alger, and all Christian and Catholic men generally explain a different doctrine?
        </s>
        <break time="500ms"/>
        <s>
            In section number 26, the writer states on page 293 of the Amsterdam edition that in both symbols, it is taught that only Christ is indicated, who feeds the souls of believers.
        </s>
        <s>
            He subtly avoids or rather precisely denies with that clever word that in one symbol Christ is only indicated, while in the other he is also contained; of which there is no faint trace in the whole work.
        </s>
        <s>
            He also denies that the wicked partake with their teeth, since he only feeds the souls of the good.
        </s>
    
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
RESPONSIO. Quaero jam a dissertatore an sibi fingat aliquid
comedi corporaliter sensim et cum sensu in perceptione
sacramenti ore corporeo, nisi quod sensibus
accommodatum et obnoxium est? Vultne persuadere
nobis ipsum verum corpus Christi comedi ad modum
obsoniorum consuetorum, dentibus frustatim
discerpi ac partitim deglutiri? Haec opinio a nemine
homine arcte teneri aut accurate defendi potest. Quid ergo illi incommodat in his Ratramni verbis? Nunquid non species sacramentales solitariae corporaliter
comeduntur seu dentibus conteruntur, et partitim
per canalem laryngis in thoracem sensim et
cum sensu sicut manna demittuntur? An aliam doctrinam
explicant Paschasius, Algerus et omnes generatim
et generaliter homines Christiani et Catholici
 viri? XXXIII. Quare num. 26, inquit dissertator, pag. 293 edit. Amstelod., in utroque symbolo Christum
duntaxat innui docet, qui credentium pascat animos;
dissimulatque, vel negat precise potius, eo verbo callidus
veterator, in altero Christum innui solum, in
altero etiam contineri; cujus rei nullum in toto opere
vel tenue vestigium est. Negat et malorum dentibus
primi, cum bonorum solummodo animos pascat.
